content:
yeah much better, the less parts the better imo

reality really is the only thing to experience, so the brain would be part of that too. which would bring you to "one experience" or "one reality". the gist is that it all happens at once together at the same time. hence the "unity" aspect. Like how dreams are self-contained.

you can imagine being in a dream and that if you tried to find what produces the dream it would only cause you to create a model of the dream (example: maybe my brain or god is creating the dream), but that is the dream. Similarly, the brain seems like an attempt to find a producer of reality but that would have to be reality as well. This recursion happens because it's overlooked that there is really simply just one experience or one reality where everything happens. It's like trying to get actors on a theatre stage to display what is creating the stage.

there isn't "perceiving later" or "perceiving in the past". Now or never. if it's not happening alongside everything else, then it isn't.

It seems like a lot of false equivalencies are being made on your part. For example, I never said reality was random. You don't have to go down that rabbit hole of deducting whether reality is random or not. That's just more thinking and theorizing. 

What is being pointed to is the simplest and most obvious thing there is, your current experience, which is the only thing you ever experience.

Thinking is really like drawing on a whiteboard in real time. Or reading a book in real time. There aren't divisions in the book or whiteboard. There's one whiteboard and one book.  Everything happens on that book or whiteboard at the same time. 

Thinking appears as divisions, but they all appear now, which means they all happen together at once.

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1275195736589598831/1278863770634027028

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1285013640327598110

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1287056370746789908/1287171147229827257

> Though I still have a few questions left, why are memories so coherent with reality to the point we believe we can make the past out of them? And why can people have memories relating to one another (e.g you and I remembering this  conversation)?

Why do you think these questions are relevant?

In the sense, have you ever had to time travel to view a memory? Or go to yesterday in order to know what you did yesterday? Or go back to a conversation to know you were having a conversation?

You're mistaking the map for the territory. Time is a model (map). There isn't "time" and "those models", there is time which is a model.

A baby doesn't need to believe in gravity to stay anchored to the Earth. It doesn't worry that if it stops believing in gravity it will float off the Earth. It has no model of gravity. Yet it experiences gravity and its experiential reality operates in relation to gravity.

Taking that to time, if you stop believing in the model, it actually vanishes entirely. This is unlike gravity. Because time is inherently a model, unlike gravity. It's not there. If you believe it is there outside of the model, that is the belief in the model, which is to say, you believe it exists outside the model. And that is being lost in the map, overlooking the territory you are actually in.

there is no "how" as there is no attachment that has ever actually transpired. its important that you dont put the cart before the horse, so that you dont go around looking for santa's elves, so to speak. what is this attachment to time you're talking about?

if it's not clear enough, you might as well just put all your beliefs aside and go for certainty instead. try to attach yourself to time. go to the past or future, right now. once you are in the past or future, let me know. then we will have something to work with.

what you're looking for is already the case. any form of recognition or coherence which is currently in your experience....is currently in your experience.  not in the past in your experience, or in the future in your experience. none of the qualities of your experience have ever required time, you're just assuming it does.
